p: Climate-related range shifts are discernable across the globe for many animal species [ 1] and clear fingerprints related to climate change are detectable on bird species assemblages [ 2, 3]. Mountain ecosystems are among the most at risk from climate change [ 4]. Mountains often have high levels of biodiversity and harbour large numbers of endemic species [ 5, 6], many of which are restricted to alpine habitats [ 7]. Such habitats are gradually being lost due to tree and shrub encroachment [ 8, 9], resulting in range contractions of alpine species at their lower altitudinal limits [ 10, 11]. With no room “at the top” for upward expansion, alpine species face habitat loss and fragmentation and, ultimately, risk of extinction [ 12– 14]. Increased competition from invasive species and low elevation generalists may further accelerate population declines for alpine specialist species under a warming climate [ 15, 16].
